rawtext: This course provides an introduction to the Moodle Learning Management System. Whether you are an Administrator, Educator or Developer, we recommend starting with this course for an overview of what Moodle can offer.

This beginner level course provides a short, high level overview of Moodle. It is recommended that you take this course before any others, if you are not already familiar with Moodle. It is suitable for everyone: educators, administrators and developers.

https://youtu.be/ax6yPMyx5gU
Webinar recordings
The following two webinar recordings are not required to complete the course. Feel free to watch them if you wish.
Before you begin, review the Course overview, Learning outcomes, Course structure and Completion and assessment information.
Moodle versions

The activities and screenshots in this course are based on the standard Boost theme and the latest version of Moodle LMS, currently 4.3. See Moodle 4.3 documentation overview and New Features 4.3 documentation.
 If your Moodle site looks different, ask your Moodle support staff about the theme and version being used.

 You can access documentation about earlier, supported versions of Moodle LMS below. This documentation includes the videos related to each version.

  • Moodle 4.2 documentation overview and New Features 4.2 documentation.
  • Moodle 4.1 documentation overview and New Features 4.1 documentation.
Completion and assessment

To complete the course you need to complete the following activities:

  • 'About this course' book (what you are reading now).
  • 'Course pre-check: What do you already know?', making at least 1 attempt - your score doesn't matter.
  • 'About Moodle', 'Moodle key features', 'Courses' and 'Users' lessons.
  • 'Introduction to Moodle: Check your understanding' quiz, achieving 80% or more.

Completing the activities

  • Some activities are automatically marked as completed based on specific criteria.
  • Some activities require you to manually mark them as done.

Make sure you complete the activities according to their completion conditions.

Course badge

Upon successful completion of this course you will be automatically awarded with the relevant badge to showcase the skills and knowledge you have obtained.
Licence

This course by Moodle Academy (Moodle Pty Ltd) is licensed under CC BY 4.0. Original resources available at https://moodle.academy.

› Read more about how you should attribute this work.
Course structure

Welcome

Find out how the course works, check your prior understanding and join in an optional general discussion.

About Moodle

Be introduced to the concept, philosophy and background of Moodle.

Moodle key features

Learn about some of the key features that make Moodle the world’s most customisable and trusted online learning solution.  

Courses

Explore Moodle's basic structure, which is organised around courses.

Users

Find out about Moodle users, roles, permissions, and other Moodle user features.

Course check

Test your understanding in the final quiz.
Course overview

Aim

In this course you will learn about Moodle LMS (Learning Management System), its general structure, and some of its defining features.

Format

This is a self-paced course without active moderation. You are encouraged to discuss ideas in the discussion forums and respond to other learners' queries.

Estimated time

The estimated time to complete this course is 1 hour.
Learning outcomes

By the end of this course, participants will be able to:

  • Describe the concept, philosophy and purpose of Moodle.
  • Identify some of the key features of Moodle - accessibility, flexibility, security, customisability.
  • Describe the primary Moodle course elements - sections, activities, resources, blocks, gradebook.
  • Describe Moodle users, roles, permissions, and other Moodle user features.
Change log

All notable changes to this course will be documented in this page.

Glossary of Moodle terms
About Moodle
Which statement about Moodle is more accurate?
Which statement about Moodle is more accurate?
Which statement about Moodle is more accurate?
Which statement about Moodle is more accurate?
The Moodle Community

As an open source platform, Moodle LMS has a large community that has grown around the project. Since humble beginnings in 1999, thousands of developers, system administrators, educators and learners have participated by fixing bugs, writing new features, updating documentation, sharing tips, helping new users, sharing resources and debating new ideas.

The Moodle community contributes to and supports the evolution of Moodle LMS in an ongoing cycle of improvement.

› Want to be involved? Join the Moodle community.
The open source way

The term “open source” refers to something people can modify and share because its design is publicly accessible.

In the case of Moodle LMS (and associated projects such as Moodle Apps and MoodleNet), the “source code” is licensed under an "open source" license. Therefore, it allows anyone to:

  • download the software for free;
  • change how it works by writing new code;
  • add features to it; and
  • resolve faults.

At Moodle we follow the four freedoms that traditionally define open source:

The freedom to:

  • run Moodle LMS as you wish, for any purpose;
  • study how Moodle LMS works and change it as you wish;
  • redistribute copies so you can help others; and
  • distribute copies of modified Moodle code and extensions to benefit the entire community.

› More about open source
Welcome to Moodle

Moodle LMS, the open source learning management system used by hundreds of millions of learners worldwide, is the heart of the world’s most customisable and trusted online learning solution.

Developed in conjunction with our community, Moodle LMS is complemented by Moodle Workplace™, Moodle Apps, MoodleCloud, Moodle Academy and a network of Moodle Certified Partners and Service Providers delivering expertise in hosting, customisations, support and training.

Hundreds of thousands of organisations, in every education sector, at all types of workplaces, across every country on the globe, and in nearly every language, use Moodle as a solution to manage their online learning.

Moodle relies on a small team of in-house developers to develop new plugins and maintain all aspects of the platform.
Not quite. The Moodle community plays a huge part in developing and maintaining the platform.
The source code of Moodle can be modified and shared because its design is publicly accessible.
That's right. Because Moodle is open source, the entire software can be downloaded for free and altered.
Moodle has a huge worldwide community that contributes to writing new features and supporting the evolution of Moodle LMS in an ongoing cycle of improvement.
That's right. The Moodle community plays a huge part in developing and maintaining the platform.
Only the original authors can legally copy, inspect, and alter the source code of Moodle.
Not quite. Because Moodle is open source, the entire software can be downloaded for free by anyone and altered.

Moodle key features
Which statement about Moodle is more accurate?
Which statement about Moodle is more accurate?
Accessible

Moodle LMS is WCAG 2.1 AA compliant which means that Moodle users can be reassured that Moodle meets accessibility in four key areas. Whether you are an educator, learner, developer or system administrator, the Moodle LMS authoring and evaluation tools are endorsed by WCAG as perceivable, operable, understandable and compatible.

› More about accessibility
Moodle LMS overview

Moodle LMS is an open source, secure, feature-rich software platform that runs on any computer server and all common devices. Designed in collaboration with Moodle’s global community, it allows educators in any sector to create flexible, safe, accessible and highly engaging online spaces for their learners.

https://youtu.be/DubiRbeDpnM
Secure

Moodle’s development practices include security by design. This means that we embed a security mindset right from the start in all of our development to deliver a secure platform. As an open source platform, Moodle LMS enables you to have complete control over your data to meet your local legislation requirements, including GDPR compliance.

› More about security
Flexible

Moodle provides a pedagogical toolbox designed from a social constructionist point of view that empowers you to build your own education platform to teach the way you want, to any number of learners.

Moodle can support your online education style, whether you want to:

  • support deep collaborative learning;
  • foster peer review;
  • encourage self reflection;
  • review learners’ progress;
  • provide tasks that allow for active participation, exploration and experimentation; or
  • keep learners up to date with course requirements or changes.

Moodle supports learning from any device with the Moodle App, which improves the experience of Moodle LMS on touch screen devices and allows learners to access content, submit activities, receive notifications and complete assignments. It allows the use of Moodle in environments where learners don’t have computers or only poor internet connection.
Customise and extend

Moodle allows you to tailor your site to your needs by customising the appearance and branding (theme) and choose from a huge number of settings and built-in tools to design the perfect LMS for your needs – whether your courses are instructor-led, self-paced, blended or entirely online.

You can extend the functionality of your Moodle site with a huge ecosystem of plugins and certified integrations with third party software. From video conferencing tools, to attendance trackers, to payment gateways… you name it!
Which statement about Moodle is more accurate?
Which statement about Moodle is more accurate?

Moodle allows for one single approach to teaching and learning.
Not quite. The flexibility of Moodle lets you customise your approach to teaching.
Moodle gives you the flexibility to teach the way you want, to any number of learners.
That's right. The flexibility of Moodle lets you customise your approach to teaching.
You can give your Moodle site its own "look & feel" by customising the theme and applying your own branding.
That's right. The huge number of available themes let you modify the appearance of a Moodle site.
You can alter the appearance of your Moodle site by choosing from a handful of "out of the box" themes, however there are no further options to customise the "look & feel" of your site.
Not quite. Moodle does have a number of "out of the box" options to determine the appearance of a site; however the huge number of available themes allow you to further modify the appearance.

Activities and Resources

Activities and Resources can be added to sections within a course.

In simple terms, an Activity, such as an Assignment or Forum, refers to something students interact with or do, while a Resource such as a File or Page, refers to a more static element students will read or consume.

Moodle offers many types of activities and resources, which support collaborative learning, peer review, self reflection, active participation, exploration, experimentation, assessment and more.

› More about activities
Moodle Courses

Moodle's basic structure is organised around courses.

Courses are basically pages or areas within Moodle, where teachers can present their learning resources and provide interactive activities for students. They can have different layouts, but they usually include a number of central sections where materials are displayed; and side blocks offering extra features or information.

The course teacher has control over the layout of the course homepage and can change it at any time to support their teaching practices. 

› More about courses
A Moodle Quiz is an example of:

A Moodle 'Quiz' allows a teacher to design questions and set tests for students to undertake. Once completed, student attempts may be automatically marked, and feedback and/or correct answers may be shown. 

A Moodle Quiz is an example of:
Gradebook

Grades for each student in a course are recorded in the course gradebook, or 'Grader report'. The gradebook can consist of grades:

  • from assessable activities undertaken in the course (such as assignments and quizzes); and those
  • manually input by a teacher from assessments that students complete outside a course (like performances and presentations).

› More about gradebook
Blocks

Blocks are elements that add extra information or learning content to a course. They may be added to the side of any page in Moodle.

Moodle provides a number of standard blocks, such as:

  • activity results;
  • forum search; and 
  • course completion status. 
There are also many other contributed blocks that can be installed to further extend the functionality of a site. 

› More about blocks
Sections

Courses can be divided into sections to organise content and learning materials for students. Each section can have a custom title and description and be arranged in a different format to support different teaching practices.

Common course formats include

  • Weekly, where the course is organised week by week, with each section having a date heading.
  • Topics, where the course is organised into topic sections that can have custom titles.
  • Social, where the course is oriented around one main forum which appears listed on the main page.
  • Single, where the course has only 1 section, and allows the teacher to add only one activity to the course.
A Block might be added to a Moodle course to provide supplementary features or navigation.

True or false.

A Block might be added to a Moodle course to provide supplementary features or navigation.
Activity completion

Activity completion allows a teacher to set completion criteria in the settings of a specific activity or resource. The criterion might be:

  • viewing;
  • receiving a certain score; or 
  • a student marking it as complete.

Activity completion allows students to see which activities and resources are required in a course and gain a snapshot of their current progress.  

When used in combination with the restrict access feature, the teacher can guide a student through the course, ensuring designated activities are completed in a specific order.
True
Correct. Blocks can be used in Moodle courses to provide supplementary features and navigation.
An activity.

That's right. A Quiz is a very powerful activity that students actively participate and interact with. It can meet many teaching needs, from simple, multiple-choice knowledge tests to complex, self-assessment tasks with detailed feedback.
A resource.

Not quite. A Quiz is a very powerful activity that students actively participate and interact with. It can meet many teaching needs, from simple, multiple-choice knowledge tests to complex, self-assessment tasks with detailed feedback.

False
Try again. Blocks can be used in Moodle courses to provide supplementary features and navigation.
Users
Users

All users within a Moodle site will have the ability to access different areas of the site and perform different actions based on their role. 

Before roles can be assigned, everyone using a Moodle site must have a user account. 

A Moodle site may allow people to create their own account using Email-based self-registration (like Moodle Academy does). If enabled, systems like Google and Microsoft can log people in quickly and easily using their existing account.

Smaller organisations may create new accounts manually (either individually or by bulk creating accounts via CSV file).

In large organisations, it is common for an institution-wide login to be used.
Competencies and badges

Competencies describe the level of understanding or proficiency of a learner in certain subject-related skills. Competency-based education (CBE), also known as Competency-based learning or Skills-based learning, refers to systems of assessment and grading where students demonstrate these competencies. With Moodle, it is possible to create and apply frameworks for evaluating students against competencies in Moodle.

Badges are a good way of celebrating achievement and showing progress. Badges may be awarded based on a variety of chosen criteria and may be displayed on a users profile or pushed to their Badgr backpack. Public badge collections in their backpack can be displayed in their Moodle profile.
Roles and enrolments

Once users have an account, they can then be enrolled in a course with a specific role. The role given to them in a course is specific for that course only - they may be enrolled in other courses with another role. 

Moodle supports a variety of different user roles, with each role having its own set of permissions that allow users to have different capabilities in different contexts. The most common examples are the roles of student and teacher in the context of a course.

As with so many other aspects of Moodle, user roles can be tailored to meet the needs of a site. 

› More about roles and permissions
Which statement about Moodle roles is correct?
Which statement about Moodle roles is correct?
Messaging and notifications

Users in Moodle have multiple avenues for communicating with each other and being alerted to important events. 

As well as the different types of forums or other communication activities that may be available within their courses, teachers, students and other users are able to quickly talk to each other and stay in touch through the messaging and notification functionality. 

Users can use Messaging to contact others via real-time chat. If offline, a message recipient can be notified of messages when they log in, and can opt to receive messages via email.

› More about messaging

Notifications alert users to events in Moodle that may require their attention. This may include new forum posts, assignments needing grading or badges awarded. Users can choose how to receive notifications, whether it be by email, a notification indicator in the site, or pushed to their mobile device.

› More about notifications
Grouping users

There are a number of instances where it can be useful to separate users within a course. Moodle can facilitate this through the use of groups and groupings. Groups and groupings can be used for communication purposes, to handle student activity and interaction and to restrict access to activities and resources.

Examples of using groups include:

  • Filtering the gradebook, so teachers only see grades from one class at a time.
  • Allocating a resource to just one class or set of users.
  • Enabling students to submit an assignment as a group. 
  • Enabling students to only reply to their own group within a discussion forum.

› More about groups
Users will always have the same role in every course they are enrolled in.
Not necessarily. Users can have different roles in different courses.
Each role has its own set of permissions that allow users to have different capabilities in different contexts.
Correct. The combination of roles and context define a specific user's ability to do something on any page.

A Moodle Activity, is a tool that allows students to interact with other students, the teacher, or interactive content.

What is the term used to describe a static course element in Moodle, which students will read or consume to acquire knowledge in a passive way, and is often contrasted to an Activity?
Your answer is correct.
Your answer is partially correct.
Your answer is incorrect.
Resource

Correct. In Moodle terminology, an Activity, such as Forums or Quizzes, generally means something students can contribute to directly, whereas a Resource such as a File or Page, is a more static element presented by the teacher to them.

Forum

How can you contribute to the Moodle project?

All users of Moodle can:

  • report bugs and issues using the Moodle Tracker.
  • make use of the community forums to ask and answer questions.
  • update the Moodle docs.
  • develop new plugins or contribute changes to core Moodle code.
  • contribute to the translation of Moodle language packs.
Your answer is correct.
Your answer is partially correct.
Your answer is incorrect.
Report bugs and issues.
Correct. All users of Moodle can report bugs and issues using the Moodle Tracker.
Answer questions in the Moodle community forums.
Correct. All users of Moodle can make use of the community forums to ask and answer questions.
Update the Moodle documentation.
Correct. All Moodle users can update the Moodle docs.
Develop new plugins or contribute changes to core Moodle code.
Correct. All Moodle users can develop new plugins or contribute changes to core. Moodle code.
Translate Moodle into other languages.
Correct. All Moodle users can contribute to the translation of Moodle language packs.

Moodle is a free and open source learning management system.
How can you get a Moodle site for your course?

You can get a Moodle site for your course by:

  • Installing and running Moodle on your own servers.
  • Using MoodleCloud - a cloud-based solution for using Moodle. 
  • Using the services of a Moodle Partner, who can help set up and manage online learning platforms.
Your answer is correct.
Your answer is partially correct.
Your answer is incorrect.
Install Moodle on your own servers.
Correct. You can install and run Moodle on your own servers.
Use MoodleCloud.
Correct. MoodleCloud offers a cloud-based solution for using Moodle.
Contact a Moodle Partner.
Correct. Moodle Partners can help institutions and organisations set up their online learning platforms.
Contact Moodle HQ.

Incorrect. While Moodle HQ can provide guidance and point you in the direction of help, you can get tailored and direct support via other avenues. A Moodle Certified Service Provider can deliver expertise in hosting, customisation, support and training, or you can utilise MoodleCloud and host a site on Moodle's own web servers.

Moodle is a Learning Management System.

Which of the following can Moodle be used for?

Moodle can be used for:

  • Course management tasks, using tools like the Gradebook, Groups and Reports.
  • Content delivery using tools like the Book, File and Lesson.
  • Online assessment, using tools like the Quiz, Assignment and Workshop (for peer assessment).
  • Collaboration between learners, using tools like the Forum, Database and Wiki.
Your answer is correct.
Your answer is partially correct.
Your answer is incorrect.
Course management tasks.
Correct. Moodle is a Learning Management System, so is ideal for managing your online course, using tools like the Gradebook, Groups and Reports.
Content delivery.
Correct. Moodle can be used for the delivery of learning content, using tools like the Book, File and Lesson.
Online assessment.

Correct. Moodle has a number of tools that can be used to assess students and provide feedback. These tools include:

  • Quiz
  • Assignment
  • Workshop (for peer assessment)
Collaboration between learners.

Correct. Moodle has a number of tools that can be used for collaboration between learners. These tools include:

  • Forum
  • Database
  • Wiki
What are some of the benefits of using Moodle?

Some of the benefits of using Moodle are:

  • Anyone can install and use it.
  • Adoption of open and accessibility standards.
  • Highly modular and configurable.
  • Free and open source software.
  • A large and active community of contributors.
Your answer is correct.
Your answer is partially correct.
Your answer is incorrect.
Anyone can install and use it.
Yes, anyone can install and use Moodle.
Adoption of open and accessibility standards.
Yes, Moodle adopts open and accessibility standards.
Highly modular and configurable.
Yes, Moodle is highly modular and configurable.
Free and open source software.
Yes, Moodle is free and open source software.
A large and active community of contributors.
Yes, Moodle has a large and active community of contributors.
What kinds of organisations use Moodle?
Due to the highly flexible and customisable nature of Moodle, it is used all over the world by schools, universities, Government organisations, Non-government organisations (NGOs) and workplaces.
Your answer is correct.
Your answer is partially correct.
Your answer is incorrect.
Schools.
Correct. Moodle caters for young learners in traditional K-12 schools, distance education and home study.
Universities.
Correct. Moodle allows educators to create safe, accessible, flexible and highly engaging online spaces for learners in universities, colleges, academies or institutes.
Non-government organisations (NGOs).
Correct. Many of Moodle's features - including its open source and cloud-based delivery - make it particularly useful for NGOs.
Workplaces.
Correct. Moodle offers a customisable platform streamlining onboarding, workplace learning, automation of common processes and compliance management.
Government organisations.
Correct. Moodle's customisability caters to the unique requirements of government organisations.
What type of learning does Moodle support?
Moodle provides a pedagogical toolbox designed from a social constructionist point of view that supports active, passive, collaborative and independent learning.
Your answer is correct.

active.
Correct. Moodle supports active learning by providing activities and opportunities for learners to interact and participate in a course.
passive.
Correct. Moodle supports passive learning by offering activities and opportunities for teacher-led instruction.
collaborative.
Correct. Moodle supports students with their collaborative learning and group communication in a blended or online learning environment.
independent.
Correct. Moodle supports independent learning by providing opportunities for learners to seek out information and learn at their own pace.

Collaborative design of software before the publisher reserves licensing rights to use, modify or share it.
Not quite. While open source may (and often does) involve collaborative design, there are not restrictions on using, modifying or sharing the software.
